passages.text: RevPAR weekly & Cirsa Q2 preview
Y/Y UK RGN +4% LDN - 8%, GER - 8%, Paris +20%, FR RGN +4%, US upper mid - 1%, China - 2%, AUS +7%.

Ldn - ve (last year benefited from Taylor Swift concert), UK regs +ve and similar to last week. Paris data strong (lapping easy shoulder comps post Olympics) and Fr. regs. +ve. China - ve again after a small +ve perf. last week. Elsewhere data in line with recent trends with Germany/US - ve, AUS +ve.
RevPAR growth vs. 2019: UK RGN +38%, LDN +21%, GER +8%, Paris +36%, FR RGN +44%, China - 23%, US upper mid +17%, AUS +24%.

Trackers: IHG (OW, PT 9,600p): We estimate Q3 25 is tracking at - 0.5% y/y and +13.5% vs. '19 (vs. Q2 25 rep +0.3%/+13.7%, latest week - 2.3%/+14.4% and prior week - 0.5%/+13.8%). ACCOR (OW, PT €53): We estimate Q3 25 is tracking at +1.1% y/y, Q2 25 rep +4.1%, latest week +2.7% and prior week +1.9%. WHITBREAD (EW, PT 3,020p): UK tracker: We estimate Q2 is averaging +1.7% y/y (Q1 rep - 2.4%) and +41.6% vs. '19 (Q1 rep +34.6%), with the latest week +2.4% y/y and +34.7% vs. '19 and prior week +0.6%/+35.2%. Germany tracker: We estimate Q2 is averaging -12% y/y and +13.1% vs. '19 (vs. Q1 rep +11.7%/+8%).

Cirs (OW, PT €20) Q2 25 results preview: Q2 results on 9th Sep will be Cirsa's first reporting since IPO in July. We believe Cirsa looks set to deliver a robust Q2 with sustained margin growth in Slots Spain and strong online G&B revenue growth benefiting from Apuesta Total and Casino de Portuga acquisitions. We forecast Q2 net operating revenue of €571m, +10% y/y, and EBITDA of €185m, +9% y/y (Bloomberg Consensus €185m). Our forecasts assume c15bps growth in Q2 EBITDA margins in land- based business vs. +40bps in Q1. We expect Slots Spain to deliver another solid quarter of margin growth, similar to Q1 helped by a strong B2B performance. Casino margins are likely to remain softer y/y similar to Q1, mainly due to country mix effects in Mexico and Panama from US tariff measures, which should also weigh on Q2 EBITDA margins. FY guidance looks comfortable, and we think there is a good chance that guidance will be unchanged for now with management likely holding off until Q3 when it has better visibility on Unidesa deliveries and order book for remainder of the year and also on online M&A synergies. Unidesa's strong performance has been a key driver of margin growth for land- based operations in Q1, we expect same in Q2. If this momentum

sustains into H2, we see a good scope for full- year EBITDA guidance upgrade at Q3 results later this year. For our Q2/H25 forecasts see Figure 55. Trading on 5.4x 2026E EV/EBITDA, we find the valuation compelling given a 2025- 27E adj net income CAGR of 25%, likely guidance upgrades, and an attractive M&A roll- up story (see: Unique Asset, Attractive Prospects - Initiate at OW, 18/08/25).
We include our share buyback tracker - See Figure 13.

Overweight - The stock is expected to outperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Equal Weight - The stock is expected to perform in line with the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Underweight - The stock is expected to underperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Positive - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are improving.
Neutral - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are steady, neither improving nor deteriorating.
Negative - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are deteriorating.

Valuation Methodology: We assume the group can hold the current 11.6x 1- year forward EV/EBITDA multiple and compound, leaving the stock at €53 in 12 months' time. This implies a FY25E valuation of 13.4x.

Risks which May Impe the Achievement of the Barclays Research Valuation and Price Target: The group's revenues could be significantly affected by economic conditions, currency movements and geopolitical events as well as any future pandemics. We see the greatest downside risks relating to the macro backdrop, with hotel RevPAR and valuations highly volatile depending on GDP growth. Further crystallisation of value in the form of asset sales has the potential to be a source of positive surprise for the valuation, in our view.
Stock Rating: OVERWEIGHT  Industry View: NEGATIVE  Closing Price: EUR 15.01 (27-Aug-2025)

Historical stock prices and price targets may have been adjusted for stock splits and dividends.

Valuation Methodology: We value Cirsa at 7x 2026E EV/EBITDA at a discount to Lottomatica. The discount reflects the following: 1) Cirsa's higher retail EBITDA mix of c88% vs. Lottomatica's c40%; 2) online regulatory stability in Italy for the next 9 years under new concessions regime; 3) Lottomatica's clearer omni- channel story given the ban on above- the- line marketing in Italy, unlike Cirsa's other key markets outside Italy where Online- only players are subject to fewer advertising restrictions; 4) Lottomatica's brand synergies across retail and online, which we think Cirsa lacks.

Risks which May Impede the Achievement of the Barclays Research Valuation and Price Target: 1) Unpredictable regulatory developments, 2) macro economic drivers, 3) elevated competition in core markets, 4) FX risk, 5) tax changes, 6) high cost inflation, 7) technology problems, 8) sports results, 9) delivery of revenue and cost synergies from bolt- on M&A deals.
Stock Rating: OVERWEIGHTIndustry View: NEGATIVEClosing Price: GBp 8960 (27-Aug-2025)

On 27- Aug- 2022, prior to any intra- day change that may have been published, the rating for this security was Overweight, and the adjusted price target was 54.00.
Source: Bloomberg, Barclays Research
\*This is the closing price referenced in the publication, which may not be the last available closing price at the time of publication.
Historical stock prices and price targets may have been adjusted for stock splits and dividends.

Valuation Methodology: We set our 12- month forward price target based on the FY25E multiple we expect the group to trade at in 12 months' time, which reflects c15% EPS compounding. This results in a FY25E EV/EBITDA of c17x, implying at that time a FY26E EV/EBITDA of c16x - this reflects a de- rating from previous highs in light of heightened macro uncertainty.

Risks which May Impede the Achievement of the Barclays Research Valuation and Price Target: The group's revenues could be significantly affected by economic conditions, currency movements and one- off political events. We believe the greatest downside risks are related to the macro backdrop, with hotel RevPAR and valuations highly volatile depending on GDP growth. Upside risks can also be significant, for example, with stronger pent- up demand for leisure and business travel following the pandemic. Pricing may be another source of surprise.

**Valuation** **Methodology:** We expect the multiple to remain subdued given the macro backdrop and assume 7.5x 12m fwd EV/EBITDA for the UK and 443p for Germany.

**Risks** **which** **May** **Impede** **the** **Achievement** **of** **the** **Barclays** **Research** **Valuation** **and** **Price** **Target:** Macro - The group's revenues can be significantly affected by economic conditions. We see the greatest downside risks relating to the macro backdrop with hotel RevPAR and valuations highly volatile depending on GDP growth. An improved macro backdrop would provide upside risk. Inflation - Whitbread has a significant cost base which is subject to inflationary pressures. Should the group be unable to pass on inflation to customers, this can bring about margin pressure.

This means there are different ways to evaluate a company or an investment and so different values may be placed on certain sustainability credentials as well as adverse ESG- related impacts of companies and ESG controversies. The evolving nature of sustainable investing considerations, models and methodologies mean it can be challenging to definitively and universally classify a company or investment under a sustainable investing label and there may be areas where such companies and investments could improve or where adverse ESG- related impacts or ESG controversies exist. The evolving nature of sustainable finance related regulations and the development of jurisdiction- specific regulatory criteria also means that there is likely to be a degree of divergence as to the interpretation of such terms in the market. We expect industry guidance, market practice, and regulations in this field to continue to evolve.
